keyTakeAways: Walmart has halted job offers to foreign applicants who require H-1B visas due to the new $100,000 fee imposed by the Trump administration on H-1B visas.
The H-1B visa program is crucial for US companies to access high-skilled foreign talent, especially in tech and e-commerce sectors.
Walmart, as America’s largest private-sector employer, employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders and is now adjusting its hiring practices in response to the new visa policy.
The $100,000 fee is intended to curb perceived abuse of the H-1B program but may significantly increase costs for companies and discourage hiring of skilled foreign workers.
The policy change disproportionately affects skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B applicants.
This shift reflects broader tensions between immigration policy and business competitiveness, with major firms adapting to restrictive regulations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the United States, has paused job offers to foreign workers who require H-1B visas in response to a new $100,000 fee introduced by the Trump administration. This move reflects broader concerns about the economic impact of restrictive immigration policies, especially on high-skilled professionals from India who are central to the H-1B program. The policy shift demonstrates how corporate hiring strategies are being reshaped by political changes, potentially affecting global talent access and business competitiveness in sectors like e-commerce and technology.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
